questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea), hirsutism, and difficulty conceiving. Her BMI is 32 kg/m². Laboratory tests reveal elevated testosterone levels and a high LH:FSH ratio. Pelvic ultrasound shows multiple small follicles arranged peripherally in both ovaries. Which of the following pharmacological interventions is the most appropriate initial treatment to induce ovulation in this patient, considering her desire for conception?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Letrozole:

Aspect Details
Clinical Features Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea), hirsutism, obesity (BMI >30), infertility.
Laboratory Findings Elevated testosterone, high LH:FSH ratio (>2), insulin resistance common.
Ultrasound Findings Multiple small follicles (≥12) arranged peripherally in enlarged ovaries (“string of pearls” appearance).
First-line Ovulation Induction Letrozole is preferred for ovulation induction; it decreases estrogen production, increases FSH secretion, and promotes follicular development.
Other Treatments Metformin improves insulin sensitivity and may aid ovulation but is second-line for induction.
Clomiphene citrate was traditionally used but has lower pregnancy rates than letrozole.
Combined oral contraceptive pills regulate menses and reduce androgen levels but do not induce ovulation and are contraindicated when conception is desired.

questions.text: A 39-year-old primigravida at term is in active labor. Despite adequate contractions and full cervical dilation, the fetal head remains at +1 station with the sagittal suture in the transverse diameter of the pelvis, and the posterior fontanelle is directed towards the maternal right side.What is the most likely fetal malposition described, and what is the typical management approach if labor progress arrests?

options.label: A
options.text: Persistent Occiput Posterior; manual rotation or instrumental delivery

options.label: B
options.text: Deep Transverse Arrest; manual rotation or Cesarean section

questions.correct_answer: B. Deep Transverse Arrest; manual rotation or Cesarean section
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Deep Transverse Arrest; manual rotation or Cesarean section:

Feature Deep Transverse Arrest
Definition Arrest of fetal head in the transverse position at or below the ischial spines despite full dilation and adequate contractions.
Examination Findings Head at +1 station, sagittal suture in transverse diameter, posterior fontanelle toward one side of maternal pelvis.
Mechanism Failure of internal rotation due to poor molding, uterine dysfunction, or pelvic shape.
Common in Android or anthropoid pelvis types.
Initial Management Manual rotation to occiput anterior followed by assisted vaginal delivery (forceps or vacuum) if conditions permit.
Definitive Management If manual rotation fails or is contraindicated, Cesarean section is indicated.

questions.text: A 62-year-old obese woman, G3P3, presents with a 3-month history of intermittent postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. She has a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 15 mm.What is the most appropriate next diagnostic step for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Hysteroscopy with directed biopsy:

Aspect Details
Clinical Presentation Postmenopausal vaginal bleeding is a red flag for endometrial pathology; risk factors include obesity, diabetes, hypertension.
Endometrial Thickness >4-5 mm thickness on transvaginal ultrasound in postmenopausal women warrants further evaluation.
Diagnostic Procedures Hysteroscopy with directed biopsy allows direct visualization and targeted sampling of endometrium, increasing diagnostic accuracy.
Alternative Procedures Dilation and curettage (D&C) samples endometrium blindly and may miss focal lesions; less preferred.
Medical Management Oral progestin therapy is not diagnostic and may mask pathology; reserved for confirmed hyperplasia without atypia or as treatment.
Follow-up Imaging Repeat ultrasound without biopsy is inappropriate in symptomatic postmenopausal bleeding with thickened endometrium.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with known HIV infection (CD4 count: 45 cells/µL) presents with a 1-month history of chronic diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, and significant unintentional weight loss. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the left iliac fossa. Given the clinical suspicion of CMV colitis, which of the following is the most definitive diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Colonoscopy with mucosal biopsy:

Topic Details
Etiology CMV (Cytomegalovirus) is a herpesvirus causing opportunistic infections in immunocompromised hosts, especially with CD4 counts < 50 cells/µL.
Clinical Features Chronic diarrhea, lower abdominal pain, significant weight loss, possible fever or rectal bleeding.
Pathophysiology CMV infects colonic mucosal cells causing ulcerations, inflammation, and colitis.
Diagnostic Modalities Serum CMV IgG indicates prior exposure, not active disease. Urine CMV DNA PCR shows viral shedding but is nonspecific. Plasma CMV PCR detects viremia but cannot localize infection. Colonoscopy with biopsy visualizes ulcers and provides tissue for histology, showing enlarged cells with “owl’s eye” inclusions.
Treatment Intravenous ganciclovir or oral valganciclovir, alongside immune reconstitution with antiretroviral therapy.
Prognosis Dependent on immune recovery; untreated CMV colitis has high morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female with a history of multiple severe allergies to peanuts accidentally ingests food containing peanuts. Within minutes, she develops generalized urticaria, facial angioedema, wheezing, and lightheadedness. Her blood pressure drops to 80/50 mmHg. What is the single most appropriate immediate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Intramuscular epinephrine:

Aspect Details
Definition A severe, rapid-onset systemic allergic reaction involving multiple organ systems; potentially fatal.
Common Triggers Foods (e.g., peanuts), insect stings, medications, latex.
Clinical Features Generalized urticaria, facial angioedema, wheezing, hypotension, lightheadedness, and shock.
Pathophysiology IgE-mediated mast cell and basophil degranulation releasing histamine and other mediators causing vasodilation, bronchospasm, and increased vascular permeability.
Immediate Treatment Intramuscular epinephrine administered promptly in the mid-outer thigh.
Adjunctive Treatments Corticosteroids and antihistamines help prevent prolonged or biphasic reactions but act too slowly to be initial therapy.
Supportive Care Airway management, oxygen supplementation, intravenous fluids for hypotension, and monitoring for biphasic reactions.

Classic Tetralogy Components 1. VSD
2. Pulmonary stenosis (RVOT obstruction)
3. Overriding aorta
4. Right ventricular hypertrophy
Clinical Signs Cyanosis, especially during crying/feeding ("tet spells"), harsh systolic murmur (pulmonary stenosis)
Chest X-ray Finding Boot-shaped heart (coeur en sabot) due to RVH and upturned apex
Definitive Treatment Intracardiac repair: VSD closure and RVOT/pulmonary stenosis relief (e.g., infundibular resection, patch)

questions.text: A 38-year-old nulliparous woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia) and pelvic pressure for the past 6 months. She also reports increased urinary frequency. On bimanual examination, the uterus is enlarged, firm, and irregularly shaped. Transvaginal ultrasound confirms multiple uterine fibroids, with the largest being 8 cm, located submucosally. Considering her desire to preserve fertility, which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management option for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

Aspect Details
Clinical Features Menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, urinary frequency, enlarged irregular uterus.
Common Types Submucosal fibroids (projecting into the uterine cavity) are most associated with heavy bleeding and infertility.
Diagnostic Confirmation Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line imaging for detecting fibroids and their location.
Preferred Surgical Option Laparoscopic myomectomy allows targeted removal of fibroids with minimal invasiveness, preserving uterine integrity for future fertility.
Alternative Options Hysteroscopic myomectomy may be used if fibroids are completely intracavitary.
Role of Other Treatments Total hysterectomy eliminates fertility. UAE may impair uterine blood flow. Endometrial ablation is contraindicated in women desiring future pregnancy.

questions.text: In the given bacterial growth curve, which of the following phases denotes exotoxin production?
questions.explanation:
Phase Name Duration Key Features
A Lag Phase ~0–2 hrs Bacteria adapt to environment; no division yet
B Log (Exponential) ~2–8 hrs Rapid cell division; antibiotics most effective here
C Stationary Phase ~8–24 hrs Nutrient depletion; growth = death; exotoxin production
D Death Phase ~24–48 hrs Cell death exceeds growth; toxin levels may persist

Lag Phase
  • Phase of cellular adaptation
    • Increase in size, enzymes, and metabolites
  • Total count: Constant
  • Viable count: Constant
  • Maximum size of bacteria is at the end of lag phase

Exponential/Log phase
  • Phase of cell division
    • Number of cells increases
    • Cell size decreases
  • Total count: Increases
  • Viable count: Increases
  • Maximum metabolic activity
  • High susceptibility to antibiotics

Stationary Phase
  • Bacterial growth ceases due to depletion of nutrients
  • Viable bacteria = non-viable bacteria
  • Sporulation
  • Exotoxin production
  • Antibiotic production
  • Bacteriocin production

Decline/Death Phase
  • Phase of cell death
  • Viable count: Decreases
  • Low metabolic stage

Strategy

Rate Control

Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol), Verapamil, Diltiazem, Digoxin

Rhythm Control

Amiodarone, Flecainide, Dofetilide

Anticoagulation

Warfarin, NOACs (e.g., apixaban)

Not Used

Adenosine – Only for PSVT, not AF

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the paediatric OPD with visible severe wasting, bilateral pedal edema, and weight-for-height < -3 SD. What is the first dietary step in management?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - F-75 diet:

Aspect Details
Definition Severe acute malnutrition characterized by weight-for-height < -3 SD, visible wasting, and/or nutritional edema.
Clinical Features Severe wasting, bilateral pedal edema (kwashiorkor), lethargy, and increased susceptibility to infections.
Initial Dietary Management F-75 diet is given first; it is low in protein and sodium, provides 75 kcal/100 ml, and supports metabolic stabilization without overwhelming the child’s compromised system.
Transition Phase After stabilization, transition to F-100 diet (100 kcal/100 ml), which is higher in protein and energy for rehabilitation and weight gain.
Therapeutic Feeding Total therapeutic feeding of approximately 125 kcal/kg/day is the target during rehabilitation, not the initial step.
Home-made Diet Not suitable initially due to unpredictable nutrient content and risk of refeeding syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with new-onset tremors, ataxia, and jaundice. On examination, a brownish-green discoloration is noted at the limbus of both corneas. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the primary therapeutic strategy for this patient's condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Copper chelation therapy or zinc supplementation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Copper chelation therapy or zinc supplementation.
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Copper chelation therapy or zinc supplementation:

Aspect Details
Etiology Autosomal recessive mutation in ATP7B gene → impaired copper excretion into bile → copper accumulation in liver, brain, cornea, kidneys.
Clinical Features Hepatic: Elevated liver enzymes, hepatitis, cirrhosis.
Neurologic: Tremors, ataxia, dysarthria.
Ophthalmologic: Kayser-Fleischer rings (brownish-green ring at corneal limbus).
Diagnosis Low serum ceruloplasmin.
Elevated 24-hour urinary copper.
Liver biopsy showing increased hepatic copper.
Presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings on slit-lamp exam.
Treatment Copper chelators: Penicillamine or trientine to promote copper excretion.
Zinc: Induces metallothionein, which blocks copper absorption.
Liver transplantation: Reserved for fulminant hepatic failure or end-stage liver disease.
Prognosis Early treatment improves prognosis and prevents irreversible organ damage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoing a routine pre-employment check-up had the following chest X-ray. He is asymptomatic. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiological finding?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Pulmonary hamartoma:

Topic Details
Definition Benign lung tumor consisting of an abnormal mixture of cartilage, fat, connective tissue, and sometimes bone.
Epidemiology Most common benign lung tumor
Typically occurs in adults aged 40-60 years
Pathology Composed mainly of cartilage and fat
Well-circumscribed, often “coin lesion” on chest X-ray
Radiological Features Solitary, round, well-defined nodule
Popcorn-like calcifications (coarse, chondroid calcifications) are hallmark
Usually located peripherally
Clinical Presentation Most patients asymptomatic
Often incidental finding during imaging for other reasons
Natural History & Prognosis Slow growing or stable
Benign with excellent prognosis
Rarely requires surgical removal unless symptomatic or diagnosis uncertain
Condition Key Features
Bronchogenic carcinoma Malignant lung tumor
Usually irregular, spiculated mass
Calcification if present is eccentric or stippled
Associated with smoking and symptoms like cough, weight loss
Tuberculoma Localized granuloma due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Dense, central calcifications but no popcorn pattern
Often history of TB exposure or symptoms
Metastasis Usually multiple pulmonary nodules
Calcification rare, if present usually amorphous or irregular
History of extrapulmonary malignancy common

Condition

Common Location

Initial Imaging Modality

Pulmonary Hamartoma

Lung parenchyma

Chest X-ray / CT Thorax: "popcorn" calcifications in peripheral nodules

Involuting Fibroadenoma

Breast

Mammography: Coarse, popcorn-like calcifications

Enchondroma

Small bones (hands/feet)

X-ray: Central lucency with speckled, "popcorn" calcifications

Chondrosarcoma

Pelvis, femur, ribs

X-ray / CT: Popcorn or ring-and-arc calcifications in large lesions

Degenerating Uterine Fibroid

Uterus

Pelvic Ultrasound: Echogenic, coarse calcified mass

Cavernoma

Brain

MRI: Popcorn/Mulberry calcification

questions.text: Which of the following cellular changes is considered the critical point of no return, indicating irreversible cell injury?

Correct Option C - Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis of the nucleus:

Stage Change Reversibility
Early Cellular swelling due to ATP depletion and Na⁺/K⁺ pump failure Reversible
Early Detachment of ribosomes from rER → ↓ protein synthesis Reversible
Early Switch to anaerobic glycolysis → ↓ pH, lactic acid buildup Reversible

questions.text: Match the Hodgkin Lymphoma variant in Column A with its most characteristic pathological feature in Column B Column A Column B 1. Nodular Sclerosis a. Classic RS cells 2. Mixed Cellularity b. Popcorn cells (L&H cells) CD 15+ 3. Lymphocyte-Rich c. Polymorphic inflammatory background 4. Lymphocyte-Depleted d. Lacunar cells 5. Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant e. Pleomorphic RS cells f. Popcorn cells (L&H cells) CD 30- Choose the correct set of matches:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B: 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-e, 5-f

Subtype

Morphology and Immunophenotype

Nodular Sclerosis

Frequent lacunar cells and occasional diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate composed of T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells. Fibrous bands divide cellular areas into nodules. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; usually EBV-.

Mixed Cellularity

Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes, eosinophils, macrophages, and plasma cells. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; 70% EBV+.

Lymphocyte-Rich

Frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. Background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; 40% EBV+.

Lymphocyte-Depleted

Reticular variant: Frequent diagnostic RS cells and variants and a paucity of background reactive cells. RS cells CD15+, CD30+; most EBV+.

Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant

Frequent L&H (popcorn cell) variants in a background of follicular dendritic cells and reactive B cells. RS cells CD20+, CD15-, CD30-; EB-.

Feature Complete Mole Partial Mole

Fetal Tissue Absent Present (but abnormal fetus)
Ultrasound Finding “Snowstorm” or cluster of grapes appearance, no fetal pole Abnormal fetus + cystic placenta
Uterine Size Larger than gestational age May be normal or slightly increased
β-hCG Levels Markedly elevated (>100,000 mIU/mL common) Mildly to moderately elevated

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with schizophrenia has been progressively declining in functioning over the past 3 years. He shows marked social withdrawal, emotional blunting, and poor hygiene. There are no features of hallucinations or delusions. What is the prognosis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - W

Paranoid schizophrenia
  • M/c subtype
  • Predominantly delusions and haliucinations
  • Late-onset
  • Good prognosis
  • Personality is preserved

Hebephrenic or disorganized
  • Disorganized symptoms (giggling/smiling to self/mirror gazing)
  • Early onset
  • Poor diagnosis
  • Severe personality deterioration

Catatonic schizophrenia
  • Mostly, catatonic symptoms + other symptoms
  • Treatment: Lorazepam I.V. (1" line treatment)
  • Electro Convulsive Therapy (ECT) → Best treatment
  • Best prognosis

Residual schizophrenia
  • Early stage of delusions and hallucinations
  • Later, it becomes minimal delusions and hallucinations
  • Mostly shows negative symptoms

Undifferentiated schizophrenia
  • Features of >1 Subtype (Mixture of symptoms)

Simple schizophrenia
  • Predominantly negative Symptoms
  • Worst prognosis
  • ICD-10: symptoms present > 1 year → simple schizophrenia

Post schizophrenic depression
  • Schizophrenia (in past one year) → symptoms improved → later develop depressive symptoms
  • ↑ risk of suicide

- Oral ulcers
- Symmetrical polyarthritis (small joints)
- Hematologic: leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
Pathophysiology Autoantibody production (ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Sm) → immune complex deposition → inflammation and organ damage.
Treatment Goals - Control symptoms
- Prevent flares
- Minimize organ damage
- Improve quality of life and survival
Medication Role Indications and Notes
Hydroxychloroquine Cornerstone baseline therapy - Modulates immune response
- Decreases flare frequency
- Improves survival
- Safe for all patients regardless of severity
Corticosteroids Rapid symptom control during flares - Used in moderate to severe flares
- Not suitable as long-term monotherapy due to side effects
Mycophenolate Mofetil Immunosuppressant for severe disease - Mainly used in lupus nephritis and severe organ involvement
- Not first-line for all patients
Belimumab Biologic agent for refractory disease - Used in patients who fail standard therapy
- Targets B-cell survival factor BLyS
NSAIDs Symptomatic relief - Helpful for arthralgia and mild symptoms
- Does not modify disease course

Option Reason for Exclusion
Mycophenolate Mofetil (Option A) Used mainly for moderate to severe SLE such as lupus nephritis; not appropriate as initial therapy for all patients.
Belimumab (Option B) Reserved for refractory SLE cases after standard treatments fail; not first-line therapy.
Hydroxychloroquine (Option C) Correct choice as baseline, cornerstone therapy for all SLE patients.
High-dose corticosteroids (Option D) Useful for controlling severe flares but not suitable for long-term maintenance due to significant side effects.

Antigenic drift Gradual accumulation of point mutations Seasonal flu epidemics
Point mutation Single nucleotide substitution Part of antigenic drift
Nonsense mutation Point mutation introducing premature stop codon Rare in influenza; not pandemic-related

Causes major epidemics and pandemics   Does not cause 
Seen in influenza A  Seen in Influenza A and B

Virus A

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of fever, severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia. Lumbar puncture is performed, and CSF analysis reveals elevated WBCs, proteins, and decreased glucose. Gram stain of the CSF shows gram-negative diplococci. Medium Selectivity Purpose / Use Relevant Organism
Modified Thayer-Martin Agar Selective Enriched with antibiotics (V-C-N-T) to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis Neisseria species (esp. from sterile or contaminated sites)
Chocolate Agar Enriched Supports growth of fastidious organisms (e.g., H. influenzae, Neisseria) but not selective Good for general Neisseria growth

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida in active labor at 6 cm cervical dilation is being monitored with continuous cardiotocography (CTG). The CTG tracing shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 140 bpm, moderate variability, and recurrent late decelerations following uterine contractions. The contractions are occurring every 3 minutes and lasting 60 seconds. What is the most appropriate initial intervention for this fetal heart rate pattern?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer intravenous oxytocin to augment labor

options.label: C
options.text: Reposition the mother to her left lateral side and administer oxygen

options.label: D
options.text: Perform an amniotomy to assess amniotic fluid

questions.correct_answer: C. Reposition the mother to her left lateral side and administer oxygen
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Reposition the mother to her left lateral side and administer oxygen:

Parameter Description
Baseline FHR 110–160 bpm is normal; 140 bpm here is within normal limits.
Variability Moderate variability (6–25 bpm) indicates reassuring fetal oxygenation status.
Late Decelerations Gradual decrease in FHR starting after the peak of contraction; suggests uteroplacental insufficiency.
Causes of Late Decelerations Maternal hypotension, uterine hyperstimulation, placental insufficiency.
Initial Management Repositioning mother (e.g., left lateral), administering oxygen, IV fluids; stop oxytocin if being used.
Escalation of Care If decelerations persist despite conservative measures, further interventions (e.g., cesarean) are considered.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory tests is considered the most definitive for diagnosing Von Willebrand Disease (VWD) and characterizing its type?

Test Purpose Role in Diagnosis
Platelet count (CBC) Screens for thrombocytopenia Usually normal in VWD
Factor VIII activity VWF stabilizes FVIII in plasma Often mildly reduced in VWD
VWF:Ag (antigen) Measures quantity of VWF Helps detect Type 1 (↓), Type 3 (absent)
VWF:RCo (ristocetin cofactor activity) Measures functionality of VWF – platelet binding Most specific and essential for subtyping

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-week history of amenorrhea, mild lower abdominal pain, and light vaginal spotting. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus and a complex adnexal mass in the right fallopian tube, measuring 2.5 cm, with a fetal pole and cardiac activity. Her serum β-hCG level is 3500 mIU/mL. She is hemodynamically stable.Given her stable condition and the ultrasound findings, which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Immediate laparoscopic salpingectomy

Aspect Details
Clinical Presentation Amenorrhea, lower abdominal pain, and light vaginal bleeding in early pregnancy.
Diagnostic Tools Transvaginal ultrasound and β-hCG.
Key Imaging Finding Empty uterus with complex adnexal mass + fetal pole + cardiac activity confirms tubal ectopic pregnancy.
β-hCG Level 3500 mIU/mL - well above the discriminatory zone; absence of intrauterine pregnancy is significant.
Management Criteria Hemodynamic stability alone does not justify conservative or medical therapy if cardiac activity is present.
Preferred Treatment Laparoscopic salpingectomy is indicated for ectopic pregnancy with cardiac activity or large size (>3.5 cm) or rupture.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a fixed belief that her husband has been replaced by an impostor who looks identical to him. She becomes agitated when questioned and insists, “he looks the same, but he’s not my husband.” What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C - Capg

1. Capgras syndrome

  • Patient believes that someone who is closely related to him has been replaced by an exact double
  • Physical appearance remains the same.
  • Fighting with a close person
  • CAPGRAS: Close Person Replaced by Stranger
  • Seen in Lewy body dementia


 

2. Fregoli syndrome

  • Patient believes that a familiar person is imposing as a stranger and can take multiple appearances
  • Physical appearance is different
  • Fighting with a stranger

 

3. Syndrome of intermetamorphosis

  • Patient believes that others undergo changes in physical and psychological identities into entirely different people

4. Syndrome of subjective doubles

  • Delusional belief of the existence of physical duplicates of self, living in different parts of the world

questions.text: According to the NRP 2021 neonatal resuscitation guidelines, what is the indication to start chest compressions?
questions.correct_answer: C. Heart rate <60/min despite adequate ventilation
questions.explanation:
Correct Option C -Heart rate <60/min despite adequate ventilation:

Parameter NRP 2021 Guideline Recommendation
Initial Step Provide warmth, clear airway, dry, and stimulate.
HR <100/min Initiate positive-pressure ventilation (PPV).
HR <60/min after 30 sec of PPV Ensure effective ventilation, then start chest compressions with PPV (3:1 ratio).
Chest Compression Technique Two-thumb encircling hands technique on lower third of sternum.
Compression:Ventilation Ratio 3:1 (90 compressions + 30 breaths per minute = 120 events/minute)
Medications (if HR still <60) Epinephrine via umbilical vein access may be indicated after 60 seconds of compressions + PPV
